title: Bankers chase dwindling invites to block party
text:
There is also Jacobs Engineering's $700 million parcel of Worley shares, which the American firm took as part of consideration for its Energy, Resources and Chemicals division last year.

There are also blocks in Oil Search, and the long talked-about one – but one that has been very slow coming – is China Investment Corp's $2.44 billion stake in Goodman Group.

Further down the list are billionaires' stakes in companies they founded – think the Stokes' shares in Seven Group or Richard White's shareholding in WiseTech Global – given recent selling by the Lowys, Murdochs and James Packer, among others.

It remains to be seen whether any of the above see the light of day. But given the time of the year, and conditions where secondary blocks and equity raisings are flying out the door, you can bet bankers will be pitching.

It comes as Macquarie's equities desk got in on the action on Thursday, handling a $370 million stake in listed salary packaging firm Smartgroup.

As first reported by this column, Macquarie was seeking buyers for 32 million shares, representing a 25 per cent stake in the company.

The block came only two days after Smartgroup had fronted fund managers at the annual Citi conference and was done at a 6.6 per cent discount to the last close. It's one that had been on watchlists since Smartgroup listed on the ASX in July 2014.

And it's been only one day since perennial league table leader UBS sold the Lowy family's $815 million stake in Westfield Australia and New Zealand malls owner Scentre Group.

In what was a power move by UBS, coming on the same day Latitude Financial Group formally pulled its IPO, the deal was soon covered by a small handful of existing and new shareholders in the shopping centre owner.

The Swiss bank also split the $1.36 billion Ramsay Health Care trade with JPMorgan last month.
description: Equities desks are in a spin as the list of block contenders shortens by the day.
